thread.section_title: Commodities Market News - Yahoo!7 Australia Finance
thread.title: Bonds boosted, tracking US treasuries

title: Bonds boosted, tracking US treasuries
text:
Fri, Jul 31, 2015, 9:19 AM AEST - Australia Markets open in 41 mins. Bonds boosted, tracking US treasuries AAP â€“ 25 minutes ago Print 
The Australian bond market has rallied, following a positive lead from global markets. 
Nomura head of macro products Jon Linton said US treasuries had been boosted by US gross domestic product data, which grew at an annualised pace of 2.3 per cent in the second quarter, slightly missing expectations or 2.5 per cent. 
"On one hand you've got the Federal Reserve who seem very keen to hike rates, but on the other hand you've got slowing growth and mixed data in the US," he said. 
"So, that's causing the US curve to flatten and ours is flattening in sympathy." 
Mr Linton said the Australian Reserve Bank's reluctance to cut rates, amid below-trend growth in the economy would help the curve flattening bias domestically. 
At 0830 AEST on Friday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.185 (implying a yield of 2.815 per cent), up from 97.120 (2.880 per cent) on Thursday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.090 (1.910 per cent), up from 98.050 (1.950 per cent). 
KEY MOVEMENTS: 
* CGS 5.5pct Jan 2018, 1.901%, unchanged from Thursday 
* CGS 4.25pct April 2026, 2.930%, unchanged 
Sydney Futures Exchange prices: 
* September 2015 bill futures, 97.900 from 97.910 
* December 2015 bill futures, 97.960, from 97.930 
(*Closes taken at 1630 AEST previous local session) 
Source: IRESS
